is the place to go for Dutch motorsports fans, as it is home to the TT Circuit where the Dutch TT Race is held. For a weekend in June, this town turns into a bustling, crowded destination full of partying fans, when the Dutch TT, part of the worldwide MotoGP, is taking place. If you're not a motorcycle afficionado, this capital of the

is probably not a particularly interesting city for you, but with some 65000 inhabitants it's a rather large town and a regional centre for shopping and services. If you do find yourself here, don't miss visiting the Drents Museum, which has a very nice collection on local and general history. Assen is also useful as a transport hub, since many buses to small villages commence their run here and the city is served by fast intercity trains.
It's easy to get in here by car or motorcycle, as Assen lies on the major

(north - south) and is furthermore connected via provincial roads in every other direction.

Assen is a stop on the fast intercity
. Intercity trains run every half hour, connecting Assen to Groningen in the north and

and Amsterdam in southern and western direction. There's also a slightly slower "Sprinter" train connection to Zwolle, stopping at the smaller stations of Beilen, Hoogeveen and Meppel on the way.

Many

traverse the countryside, and Assen is a hub in this network. Most nearby destinations (noth large and small) are connected via the cities busstation, which is located near the train station

Groningen Eelde

is just 18 km away. From there you can take a bus or taxi. However, it serves only a limited number of international destinations, mostly via discount carriers. Head to Amsterdam Schiphol for major flight connection.
It's an excellent place to cycle around and in. The LF9 and LF14 national cycle routes pass near to Assen.

The city centre of Assen is small enough to get around on foot.

Assen is the capital of the cycling province of Drenthe. It is a wonderful place to cycle. Hire a bicycle and travel around. Various companies provide tours of the area, some English speaking.

value: content=This bike shop at the train station rents out bikes too.
hours=Tu-Su 11am-5pm. During public holidays also on Mondays.

content=The Drents Museum is one of the best ways to spend your time in town, with good and varied historic collections in archaeology and arts. Highlights include several displays of bog bodies and what's believed to be the world's oldest boat, a prehistoric canoe built around 8000BC. It's art section has some excellent works and includes a Vincent van Gogh.
content=A monumental mansion in the centre of town. It was built in 1778 and has beautiful English gardens.
price=From €10 for tickets to see a race

content=Famous for motorsports fans in all the world, the TT circuit was built in 1955 and, although originally longer, the track is now some 4,555m long. The sports arena can host some 100.000 spectators, and in fact does when the DutchTT in running. Usually held in June, this is the largest single day sports event in the country, drawing visitors from far and wide. Check the websites for any upcoming events, as there are events some 250 days of the year. After the track was shortened, a large area of land became available to develop the Circuit into a more full-fledged tourist attraction in Assen. Heavy investments are currently made to create a large scale leisure park around the circuit, including shopping and amusement opportunities.

There are enough restaurants to choose from, especially on and around the market square.

value: content=This place has the looks and atmosphere of a simple bistro or pub, but its dishes are restaurant quality stuff. If you're not too picky, try the surprise menu.
content=Nice place with international style dishes. When in season, they sell a pretty good pan full of mussels.
content=This Italian place gets a bit noisy when it's busy and the service is not the fastest around, but the pizza's and pastas are good.
content=The most popular Indian restaurant in town, with friendly service and a very extensive menu. If you want to be sure of a table, it's best to call ahead.
content=Groningerstraat 57. Italian restaurant. Main €20. Open 5pm-10.30pm. Closed Mondays.

As the provincial capital, Assen has the full range of common stores, including many large chain companies. The main shopping streets include the Forum, Gedempte Singel, the recently renovated Mercuriusplein, the Kleuvenstee, Koopmansplein and Kruisstraat. A large restructure plan for the city centre includes the establishment of a new, covered shopping mall called

. Although the full centre plan is still being carried out, the shopping area has opened with several large stores including a supermarket and a large electronics store. Despite its wide choice of shops however, Assen is generally not considered the most "cosy" or fun shopping city around.

On both Wednesday and Saturday there is a market. In 2008 this market won the award of "gezelligste markt" in the Netherlands. i.e. the most friendly and pleasant in the country.

The tourist office tries to market Assen as the regional place to be for a night out. It's not entirely true, but there are a number of pleasant bars in the town centre where you can enjoy a beer and a good conversation, and on a warm summer's night join the locals and kick back on one of the outdoor terraces. The
has a few bars, including a pool and darts café called
Other good streets to start are the
. On weekends, many of the young people in Assen jump on a late night train to the more trendy university city

, where bars and clubs are open very late and which is a 15 minute train ride. They take the first train back in the morning. If you're not up for staying awake till daylight, there are a few clubs in town, including
where, although crowded with teens, you can get rid of your dance vibes if you want.

value: content=A two story apartment with separate bedroom, kitchen, diningroom and livingroom. Nicely decorated in the style of the 1900s.
content=Although the interior is a bit outdated, this hotel offers spacious rooms with all the basic facilities right in the city centre. On weekends, rooms in the front can be a bit noisy.
content=Convenient location for a visit to the TT, with spacious, well-equipped rooms. It's outside of the city centre, though.
content=This place is located on the edge of Assen, near the Asserbos, but has good facilities including indoor and outdoor pools, an extensive spa, and bowling alley, most of them free.
price=€70/79 for a standard or deluxe double room

content=Small, charming hotel in a small village some 10km from Assen. It's run by a couple and has a great restaurant with a daily menu. They offer bike rental and upon request they'll arrange for flowers or chocolates in your room.

providing all basic postal services can be found in most supermarkets and several bookshops. They follow the host stores opening hours, which typically means till 6pm for bookshop and 8pm for supermarkets. The most convenient examples in the city centre are:
